div.head: Memorandum of Conversation Among HO, EUR, and British Embassy Officials
div.p: Subject: Publication of Documents on Iran for 1952-1954

list.item: Richard J. S. Muir, First Secretary of the British Embassy
H. L. Dufour Woolfley, EUR/NE, Country Officer for the United Kingdom
John P. Glennon, PA/HO, Associate Historian for Asia, Africa, and the Pacific
Paul Claussen, PA/HO, Chief, African and Southwest Asian Group

div.p: Mr. Muir stated that he had learned from the Iran Desk that the Department was currently reviewing papers dealing with Iran for the period 1952-1954 for publication in the series Foreign Relations of the United States. He noted that the U.S. and U.K. Governments had worked closely with respect to Iran during that period, and that it now was a matter of concern because developments during that period related to the current situation in Iran. Mr. Muir then raised two specific points. First, could the U.S. give the U.K. an assurance that it will remove from these papers any specifically British documents? Secondly, the U.K. hoped that the U.S. would raise with it the question of what was included and what was edited out. Papers of U.S. origin might contain information concerning British views, and the U.K. hoped it would be possible to arrange a joint approach with a view to taking out embarrassing papers.

With respect to the first point, Mr. Glennon replied that the texts of all British documents, or direct quotations therefrom, would be sent to the U.K. for clearance. With respect to the second point, he noted that there was no precedent for the U.S. to consult with any foreign government concerning the publication of documents other than those originated by that government. The U.K. did not refer its own documents to the U.S. prior to publication. It was ultimately a question of sovereignty. The Department’s longstanding practice was to notify a government that the U.S. was working on a volume covering a particular subject at the time the documents were presented for clearance, and once again about ten days before public release of the volume.

Mr. Glennon and Mr. Claussen described the procedure by which the Foreign Relations series was edited and cleared, and emphasized that there was no likelihood that material on Iran would be published in the near future. The volume was under review by the Iran Country Director, and this process alone would probably take at least a year. With the addition of another year for indexing and printing, the earliest possible release date would be 1980.

Mr. Muir expressed the view that Iran in 1952-1954 was one of the relatively few situations around the world during those years that still had a direct bearing on current developments. The U.K. might take the approach of asking for a delay in publication of material on Iran for 1952-1954 if recent developments in Iran continued to be sensitive, and he wondered whether there had ever in the past been requests for delay in publication by foreign governments or by desks in the Department of State. He cited the Foreign Relations volume on Israel for 1948 as a possible example of this. Mr. Glennon replied that there had been no requests for delay by foreign governments, but that in occasional cases, such as that of China for 1949, the Department did not publish a volume until the complete record could be released. Mr. Claussen explained that publication of the volume on Israel for 1948 had not been delayed for any reasons of political sensitivity, but rather to allow time for the editors to review and incorporate papers of President Truman that had long been tied up in the Truman estate. Sensitive developments were buffered by being presented in context in Foreign Relations and neither the volume on Israel for 1948 nor any other recent volume had attracted much notice in the press. Unlike some individual requests for documents under the Freedom of Information Act, Foreign Relations volumes were not regarded as “scoops” by reporters interested in sensational developments.

Mr. Woolfley emphasized in conclusion that because U.S. and U.K. interests in Iran were identical, U.K. interests would surely be covered by the U.S. review process. Mr. Muir said that the information he had been given was very helpful and he would report it to his government.
